Award.AwardTitle: Mechanisms of Transition Metal Catalyzed Reactions in Hydrocarbons
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award, the Chemical Catalysis Program of the Division of Chemistry is funding Professor Robert H. Grubbs of the California Institute of Technology to carry out fundamental studies on olefin metathesis catalysts based on the element, ruthenium. Olefins (organic compounds containing carbon-carbon double bonds) are a key linkage in many important organic compounds that are used for pharmaceuticals, commodity chemicals and polymeric materials. Olefin metathesis is a reaction that consists of breaking and rearranging carbon-carbon double bonds in organic molecules. The olefin metathesis reaction has revolutionized the synthesis of organic molecules relevant to natural and unnatural products for treatment of diseases such as hepatitis C and AIDS, as well as the synthesis of specialty materials. Professor Grubbs is studying ways to make the catalysts more reactive and selective than any previous catalysts. The broader impacts of the research could be wide ranging in terms of furthering the role of olefin metathesis in chemical science, advancing commercial uses of olefin metathesis, and training and educating students.

The Grubbs research group is performing synthetic, mechanistic, structural, and reactivity studies of newly designed catalysts for the olefin metathesis reaction. The present generation of catalysts is highly active but tends to give a mix of different isomers. Over the past several years, considerable progress has been made in developing catalysts for the synthesis of Z-isomers of olefins in high yield and stereoselectivity, but to make a catalyst that selectively makes the E-isomer has proven to be more difficult. The strategies used to develop Z-selective catalysts are being modified, with guidance from theoretical modeling, to design new complexes with the goal of reaching an E-selective system. The geometry of the substituents on the metallacycle controls the geometry of the double bond produced in the reaction. In the Z-selective catalyst, chelated ligand systems force the metallacycle and the N-heterocyclic carbene ligand together so that all the subsitutents on the intermediate metallacycle are forced to one side of the metallacycle. In the present work, Professor Grubss is using the same design strategies to form ligand arrays that force the substituents trans to each other in the metallacycle so that the resulting olefin will be trans (E). In addition to the applications of the E-selective catalysts, the pathway to them will test and broaden the mechanistic model for the factors that control catalyst selectivity and activity.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The olefin metathesis reaction has become a major tool of organic and polymer synthesis. Key to this reaction becoming a major tool for synthesis was the finding of well-defined catalysts that are tolerant to most functional groups. The Ru based systems were initially developed at Caltech using NSF funding. These catalysts are now used widely by synthetic organic groups in the synthesis of natural products and other highly functional molecules. In addition, the catalysts are also used for the preparation of polymers of controlled structures.

The key to all these applications has been the fundamental understanding of the mechanisms of action of the catalysts and the use of this information to design and prepare catalysts that have activities that are matched to the application. 

Part of modern science is the need to move new discoveries into technology that will benefit society.  The work in the Grubbs laboratory has opened a number of opportunities and these findings have been translated to practical opportunities. Materia, Inc was formed from a couple of precursor companies and has rights to all the technology in ruthenium metathesis technology developed in the Grubbs Laboratory at Caltech.  Through the manufacture of catalyst on a large scale and the development of applications, a number of successes have been realized. http://www.materia-inc.com

Chemicals from renewal resources: Elevance (https://elevance.com) is the result of a joint venture of Materia and Cargil.  Elevance is focused on the conversion of seed oils into fuels and chemicals using ruthenium olefin metathesis.  A 400 million pound a year biorefinery started production in 2013 in Indonesia. Products from this facility are being qualified in a wide array of applications.  

Pharmaceuticals and Organic Synthesis:  The olefin metathesis reaction using the ruthenium catalysts has become a key transformation in the synthesis of complex molecules in the academic community.  These applications have also been used in medicinal discovery chemistry and have resulted in a number of commercial pharmaceuticals.  One of the components of the drug for the cure of Hepatitis C (https://www.fiercebiotech.com/special-report/olysio-j-j-s-hep-c-approval-marks-end-of-an-era) and recently Giliad (http://www.gilead.com/news/press-releases/2017/7/us-food-and-drug-administration-approves-gileads-vosevi-sofosbuvirvelpatasvirvoxilaprevir-for-retreatment-of-adults-with-chronic-hepatitis-c-virus)) was made possible by the ability of the technology to prepare large rings that are highly functionalized.  New therapies based on stapled peptides are now in human trials at Aileron (https://www.aileronrx.com) using chemistry developed in the Grubbs laboratory in 1997.  A recent study demonstrated that approximately 20% of all natural product syntheses involved a ruthenium based olefin metathesis step.  This is a similar usage to traditional organic synthetic methods.  

Materials: The catalysts can be used to produce thermoplastics from cheap petroleum monomers.  The materials are being used a variety of applications.  The largest to date is the development of an insulation material for the coating of pipe used to recover oil under extreme conditions. (http://www.materia-inc.com/media/news/shell-selects-materias-thermal-insulation-system-for-gulf-of-mexico-project)  Numerous other applications have been developed and commercialized.  

Catalysts: The ruthenium metathesis catalyst technology has been acquired by Umicore and is being broadly commercialized. http://pmc.umicore.com 

 

Other opportunities are opened by the basic discoveries of new fundamental transformations that are based on detailed mechanistic studies.  During the last granting period one of the last important areas in metathesis is the ability to select the geometry of the double bond produced in a simple metathesis coupling reaction. Over the past several years, the problem of Z selectivity has been mostly solved. There are now Mo and W based catalysts that give high Z stereochemistry. Over the past several years, a Ru based system has been developed that provides olefin formed in simple cross metathesis reactions in > 95% Z with excellent efficiencies.  In recent studies, it has been demonstrated that a new family of catalysts developed by another group are stereoretentive and allow for the complete control of double bond geometry.  

Over the past several years, we have been using the ruthenium catalysts as initiators for the living polymerization of macromonomers to produce brush block polymers. In these systems each monomer has a short polymer attached (3-6 K Mw) attached to a polymerizable norbornene. Due to the steric congestion along the backbone these polymers show low entanglement and self-assembly into ordered structures. These systems can be controlled by the backbone length to form an array of photonic crystals that reflect from the blue to the infrared. The lamella structures of these are controlled by keeping the two blocks of similar size. This study that was initiated from curiosity is now on the commercialization through a start-up that is developing a paintable material that can be used to coat windows that will reflect infrared light and provide significant energy savings.  

Over the life time of this NSF supported research, it has been demonstrated that fundamental studies funded by the NSF can lead to breakthrough for the solution of significant problems that range from new drug discovery to solutions in energy discovery and savings.
